title: Driving a Rules Revolution
summary: The Transportation Department codifies reforms to promote innovation.. Parts of the administrative state have come under legal scrutiny in recent years as conservative judges question whether it is constitutional for unelected officials to unilaterally devise, enforce and adjudicate rules governing large parts of the economy.

summary: From taxes to education to the business climate, the Beehive State has its house in order.. Salt Lake City

summary: The NBA tries too hard to keep Brooklyn fans entertained.. Brooklyn, N.Y.

title: Measles Outbreak Brings Samoa to a Standstill
summary: Pacific island nation imposes curfew to accelerate vaccination drive after more than 60 people die. A measles outbreak in the Pacific island nation of Samoa has killed more than 60 people, prompting authorities to declare a two-day curfew to accelerate immunizations while taking aim at antivaccination groups.

title: Duncan Hunter to Resign From Congress
summary: Mr. Hunter pleaded guilty to a single count of conspiring to misuse campaign funds, with a sentencing date set for March 2020. WASHINGTON-Rep. Duncan Hunter (R., Calif.)., who pleaded guilty to misusing campaign funds earlier this week, said Friday that he will resign from Congress after the holiday season.

title: 'The Irishman' Isn't Netflix's Biggest Splash Despite Big Stars and Director
summary: Nielsen rates Martin Scorsese's megabudget mob drama behind 'Bird Box,' Netflix's best-performing original movie. Netflix Inc.'s expensive mob drama "The Irishman" attracted 13.2 million viewers in the U.S. during its first five days of availability, according to TV-ratings firm Nielsen, well short of the streaming service's best-performing movie title, "Bird Box," which cost far less to make.

title: White House Still Sitting Out House Impeachment Hearings
summary: Adopting articles of impeachment 'would be reckless abuse of power,' White House counsel says. WASHINGTON-The White House declined to participate in House impeachment hearings next week, sending a letter to the Judiciary Committee on Friday criticizing the process as baseless and unfair.

title: SEC Rejects NYSE Plan to Expand Direct Listings
summary: Move poses challenge to plans to create new alternative to traditional IPOs. The Securities and Exchange Commission rejected a proposal from the New York Stock Exchange to create a new type of direct listing that would let companies raise capital.

title: Voting-Machine Upgrade Stirs Partisan Clash in Pennsylvania
summary: Dispute shows how election security is grist for political conflict. A partisan clash is unfolding over an effort to upgrade voting systems in Pennsylvania, after Republicans accused the Democratic governor of rushing the deployment of new voting machines, some of which malfunctioned in November.

title: IMF Critic Is Named Argentina's Economy Minister
summary: Martín Guzmán, academic at Columbia University, opposes austerity measures. Argentina's President-elect Alberto Fernández on Friday named Martín Guzmán, an academic critical of the International Monetary Fund, as his economy minister.

title: Trump vs. Schiff Is a Clash of One Titan
summary: His committee's report on impeachment is weak propaganda that doesn't even try to change minds.. Hearings were hardly necessary to show that Donald Trump, in all too characteristic a fashion, took interest in his administration's Ukraine policy only when he saw a chance to lard on Ukrainian announcements that he could throw back in the face of domestic critics who questioned his 2016 legitimacy.

title: 'Free College for All' Is an Experiment That Has Already Failed
summary: In 1970 New York's City College had the best of intentions. It tried 'open admissions.' It was a bust.. The progressive Democratic presidential candidates mean well when they say they want to make a college education an entitlement. They believe that nothing but good can result from giving children from low-income families the opportunity to attend college.

title: 'Saving Jemima' Review: In Love With a Hard-Luck Blue Jay
summary: In ornithology as in life, one doesn't always choose one's subjects; they sometimes choose us.. Blue jays are widely admired for their beauty, but they're not universally loved. One obvious turn-off is that they don't sound as pretty as they look. Birdwatchers often consider the jay's name a quick handle for recalling its voice, which bird-guide author David Allen Sibley describes as a "shrill, harsh, descending scream jaaaay."

title: Photos of the Week
summary: France grinds to a halt amid a massive strike, Pelosi directs the House to draft impeachment charges, Iraq enters a new phase of uncertainty after protests and more. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: For Welch's, Zero-Based Budgeting Helps Zero In on Costs
summary: The maker of jams and juices says it has reduced costs since implementing the cost-management method. Finance chiefs, in a constant battle to manage costs, increasingly are leaning on zero-based budgeting to add more discipline to spending. Welch Foods Inc. is among the latest to adopt this strategy.

title: David Fizdale No Longer Has to Coach the Knicks
summary: The team with the NBA's worst record since 2000 fires another coach in the middle of another disastrous season.. The New York Knicks are once again pitiful. And the league's most dysfunctional team has once again resorted to firing its coach in the middle of yet another disastrous season.

summary: Indexes finished roughly flat, but these seven stocks moved on news this past week. FedEx Corp.

title: Trump Administration Weighs Putting Amazon Foreign Sites on 'Notorious Markets' List
summary: Some administration officials are advocating Amazon's inclusion on the list but no decision has been made, people familiar with the matter say. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration is considering adding some of Amazon.com Inc.'s overseas operations to a list of global marketplaces known for counterfeit goods, in what would amount to a public shaming of the e-commerce juggernaut, according to people familiar with the matter..

title: Stocks and Bond Yields Climb
summary: U.S.-China trade talks also remain in the spotlight for markets ahead of the Dec. 15 deadline for new tariffs on consumer goods. U.S. stocks and government-bond yields rose Friday after a surprisingly upbeat monthly jobs report signaled strength in the U.S. economy, offsetting some of the jitters about trade that rattled investors earlier in the week.

title: Gold Falls After Strong Jobless Report
summary: Economic indicator dulls allure of haven assets. Gold prices notched their biggest daily loss in a month Friday after robust U.S. employment data undercut the case for haven assets.

title: U.S. Government Bonds Decline After Surge in Job Growth
summary: Yield on the benchmark 10-year Treasury note rose to a recent 1.855% from 1.791% before the report. U.S. government bond prices fell Friday after data showing the economy added far more jobs than expected.

title: Peloton Backlash: Controversy Over Ads Often Is Short-Lived
summary: Fitness-equipment maker joins Nike, Gillette, Pepsi and others in facing blowback for a contentious commercial. It is rare for a company's stock to fall sharply after a poorly received advertisement, but recent history shows fitness-equipment maker Peloton Interactive Inc. shouldn't expect lasting damage from social-media backlash over its recent commercial.

title: New Sudan Leader Moves to Settle With Families of Terror Victims
summary: Prime Minister Abdalla Hamdok campaigns to mend ties with U.S., hopes to forge stability out of chaos in northeast African nation. WASHINGTON-Sudan is weeks away from reaching a settlement with families of those killed in the 1998 U.S. embassy bombings in Kenya and Tanzania, one of the last steps in getting the African country removed from the U.S. list of state sponsorsof terrorism, new Prime Minister Abdalla Hamdok said in an interview.

title: A Cross-Cultural Line of Beauty
summary: The arabesque, a decorative motif in classic Islamic architecture, went on to inspire modern European artists. The winding decorative line known as an arabesque played a consistent, if marginal, role in classic Islamic architecture. In Spain's 13th-century Alhambra palace complex, for instance, intertwining tendrils and calligraphic curlicues were used to decorate the corners of doorways and the borders of panels. But this medieval bit player took on a starring role in the 19th century, when European artists and designers moved it to the very center of their work.

title: Disney Disturbs the Force: Pleasing Star Wars Fans Complicates Saga
summary: Resume Subscription. Los Angeles

title: What Would We Do Without Experts?
summary: U.S. job growth continues to beat expectations.. There's no recession in sight as the U.S. economy continues to create new opportunities and defy the expectations of professional forecasters. Yesterday, on news of another surge in hiring among small businesses, this column asked if anything can stop the great American jobs machine. Today's Labor Department report on the whole economy adds an exclamation point to that question.

title: NSA Phone Surveillance Program Faces an End as Parties Come Together
summary: Onetime supporters say the call-detail program, hobbled by changes, no longer offers major national-security value.

title: Facebook in Talks to Add More New York Office Space
summary: Technology giants continue to expand in city since Amazon canceled plans for second headquarters. NEW YORK- Facebook Inc. is in talks to lease a landmark Manhattan building in a deal that would make it one of New York City's largest corporate tenants and help offset the lack of Amazon.com Inc.'s second headquarters earlier planned for the city.

title: Design Books That Are Beautiful (and Practical) Enough to Give
summary: For the interior-design devotee on your list, five books that combine eye-candy with valuable how-to instruction. HOW GRATIFYING it is to see a gift you've given someone put to good use. When it comes to coffee-table tomes that you might give the amateur decorator on your list, a book that illuminates as well as beautifully illustrates stands a good chance of becoming the recipient's dog-eared guide. Accordingly, we've sifted through the scores of 2019's interior design books to find the five gems that most adroitly combine brains and beauty; and, for each, we identify a giftee for whom the book could plausibly become a bible.

title: Vaping-Related Lung Illnesses Appear to Have Peaked
summary: Weekly hospitalizations for lung injuries have been declining since mid-September, according to CDC. The rate of new hospital admissions for vaping-related illnesses has dropped in the past several weeks, according to data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, suggesting that the outbreak is on the decline.

title: French Government Says Strikes Won't Force Pension Climbdown
summary: Nationwide strike cripples transportation networks for second day; prime minister promises transition period. PARIS-The French government vowed to forge ahead with its plan to overhaul the country's pensions system as France faced the second day of a massive strike that has paralyzed its cities and shut its schools.

title: Indian Police Kill Four Accused Rapists, Sparking Concern-and Praise
summary: Officers said they shot the men after they tried to grab police guns and escape; India has a history of suspicious police shootings. NEW DELHI-Indian police said they shot and killed four men Friday suspected of raping and murdering a woman in a high-profile case, sparking concern the police resorted to extrajudicial killings while receiving widespread praise from a population tired of authorities' inability to rein in rapes.

title: OPEC, Allies Finalize Deeper Oil Production Cuts
summary: Brent crude climbs after the cartel and its allies confirmed a new production pact. VIENNA-OPEC and its allies completed a new production pact to deepen their oil-output cuts, delegates said Friday.

title: Watching 'Yule Logs' on Screens: A Short, Crackling History
summary: The holiday tradition of the yule-log video started with 17 seconds of footage in 1966. It's evolved in strange ways ever since. FOR APARTMENT dwellers who yearn for the joys of cozying up to a crackling fire, Yule Log videos are as much a part of the holidays as honey ham and "Home Alone." Here's a look at how the tradition evolved.

title: Parcel, Warehousing Companies Boost Hiring for Online Sales Surge
summary: The jobs growth comes as holiday consumer sales are increasingly moving from stores to e-commerce sites. Parcel delivery and warehousing companies hired in big numbers last month as they geared up for the holidays by adding more than 13,000 jobs to operations closely tied to the surge in e-commerce.

title: Top U.S. Cybersecurity Officials to Depart as Election Season Enters Full Swing
summary: Loss comes as experts predict renewed interference from Russia, other adversaries. WASHINGTON-Two top government officials with broad cybersecurity and election-integrity portfolios have announced they are stepping down this month, a loss of expertise in a critical area less than a year before the 2020 presidential election.

title: DAZN Gives Away Content to Punch Up Subscriber Base
summary: Sports-streaming service released a Sylvester Stallone boxing documentary to promote a title fight on its platform. The sports-streaming service DAZN has a contrarian approach to attracting new subscribers: Create original content and put it on other platforms for viewing free of charge.

title: Caregivers Need More Recognition, Support
summary: We caregivers provide billions of dollars in care without getting paid. Many of us work full time and/or care for children. We must manage symptoms, medications, and ensure our loved one's comfort while often neglecting our own needs.. Caregivers are indeed thrown to the wolves to figure things out on our own ("Treating Disease Is No Substitute for Caring for the Ill," Review, Nov. 30). We fall short. We don't have an outlet for our rage, resentment and anger. We're tired. We lose sleep. We put on a brave face and smile through the pain, knowing that only our loved one's death will bring an end to it.

title: Seminars Are Fine, but Civility May Not Be
summary: In our age of identity politics, it is remarkable if students feel free to speak their minds regardless of group dynamics.. My first "uh-oh" reaction to Paula Marantz Cohen's suggestion that "The Seminar Course Can Save Civility" (op-ed, Dec. 2) is that she makes a faux pas in using the term civility. A good number of today's college students have been taught that civility is a manifestation of America's white patriarchy designed to reinforce white racial power and bypass black grievances (as explained in Steve Salerno's op-ed "'White-Informed Civility' Is the Latest Target in the Campus Wars," Jan. 3, 2018). Using a seminar format to box students into civility might be viewed as a racist tactic to patronize students of color. Instead of saving civility, it might be best to let it rest in peace.

title: Ford and Scorsese Portray Very Different Americas
summary: John Ford's films epitomized the noble cause of all of the common hardworking folks who contributed to building this nation.. Peggy Noonan's comparison of Martin Scorsese films with those of John Ford is almost like comparing Al Capone and Lucky Luciano to Daniel Boone and Kit Carson ("In a Land of Heroes, Gangsters and John Ford," Delcarations, Nov. 30). John Ford's films epitomize the noble cause of all of the common hardworking folks who contributed to building this nation, their difficulties, trials and the somewhat circuitous route required to bring justice to the frontier, the building of towns and a sense of community to a truly vast wilderness.

title: Meterological Divisiveness: The Wind-Chill Number
summary: The wind chill factor is the classic example of what's wrong with the news media.. Regarding Philip C. Ordway's "'Wind Chill' Is Hot Air" (op-ed, Dec. 3): The wind-chill factor is the classic example of what's wrong with the news media. News programs report the chill factor because it makes the situation appear worse than it actually is. Just give the temperature and wind speed, and let me figure it out.

title: No Safe Space for Majority Rule at Nebraska-Lincoln?
summary: Donald Trump received the votes of 59% of the voters in Nebraska in 2016.. Regarding Daniel Payne's "There's No Safe Space for Ideas on Campus 'Animal Farms'" (op-ed, Nov. 26): When a University of Nebraska-Lincoln professor who displayed a Trump sticker in his office is harassed by being reported as committing bias or inappropriate behavior, a strange version of inclusion and bias reduction is being practiced. Donald Trump received the votes of 59% of the voters in Nebraska in 2016. Does the inclusion policy at UNL include them?

title: PG&E Provides Exit Service
summary: It occurred to me that an appropriate slogan might be: "Would the last business to leave San Francisco please turn out the lights.". Regarding your editorial "Schwab Leaves San Francisco For Texas" (Nov. 29): It occurs to me that an appropriate slogan might be: "Would the last business to leave San Francisco please turn out the lights." But on reconsideration, it appears that won't be necessary. PG&E is already doing that.

title: Trump Official Says 'No Arbitrary Deadlines' for China Trade Deal
summary: Kudlow's comments leave open possibility of another delay before levies take effect Dec. 15. WASHINGTON-President Trump's top economic adviser said Friday that there are "no arbitrary deadlines" for completing a limited trade deal with China ahead of a new set of tariffs planned for this month.

title: A Film Tailor-Made for Its Times
summary: Costa-Gavras's 'Z' is docudrama as political protest..

title: A Survivor's Memories of the Charlie Hebdo Massacre
summary: In a new memoir, the French writer Philippe Lançon tries to make sense of the 2015 terrorist attack on the Paris satirical weekly. On the morning of Jan. 7, 2015, Philippe Lançon dawdled, debating whether he should go straight to the Paris offices of Libération, the French newspaper for which he is a cultural critic, or swing by the editorial meeting at Charlie Hebdo, the satirical weekly to which he contributes a regular column. He chose the latter.

title: Former Iconix Top Executives Charged in Accounting Fraud Scheme
summary: Prosecutors say the executives sought to artificially inflate the value of the company and hide their efforts from auditors and regulators. Neil Cole, former longtime chief executive of brand-management company Iconix Brand Group Inc. and brother of shoe impresario Kenneth Cole, has been charged with accounting fraud and obstruction.

title: House Passes Resolution Backing Two-State Solution
summary: Some GOP lawmakers say Democrats used vote to embarrass Israel, Trump administration. WASHINGTON-A resolution supporting a two-state solution to the Israeli- Palestinian conflict passed the House, underscoring the tension between Democrats and Republicans on policy in the region.

title: Loop Trolley in St. Louis to Close Dec. 29
summary: Financially troubled $52 million project seeks new management arrangement. The financially troubled Loop Trolley on the western edge of St. Louis will close Dec. 29, according to the company operating the $52 million project.

title: Europeans Step Up Pressure on Iran Over Nuclear Violations
summary: France, Britain and Germany will trigger a dispute mechanism if Tehran continues its prohibited moves away from the nuclear deal, diplomats say. VIENNA-European powers will take the first step towards re-imposing international sanctions on Iran in the coming weeks if Tehran further violates the 2015 nuclear deal, diplomats said.

title: Car Makers Rushing to Copy Tesla Lack One Thing: Buyers
summary: The auto industry is slimming down as it prepares for a time when electric cars rule the streets. But what if consumers aren't ready for that future yet?. It has been a tough year for the auto industry. Global sales have slipped 5% and the once-hot China market is in decline. Profits have largely stalled. Autonomous vehicles, the industry's shiniest object, need more dollars and years to go from dream to reality.

title: Fed Adds $72.8 Billion to Markets, Balance Sheet Moves to $4.07 Trillion
summary: Moves are aimed at ensuring that the financial system has enough liquidity. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York added $72.8 billion in temporary liquidity to financial markets Friday.

title: Why Oklahoma Went Back to Running the Ball
summary: Jalen Hurts' skill set prompted Sooners coach Lincoln Riley to dial back his pass-heavy attack at midseason. At the conclusion of the last two college football seasons, the starting quarterback at Oklahoma collected the Heisman Trophy at a December ceremony in New York, then walked onto a stage a few months later as the top pick in the National Football League Draft. So when former Alabama starter Jalen Hurts announced he was transferring from Alabama to Oklahoma to use his final year of eligibility, he was instantly heralded as the scion of Baker Mayfield and Kyler Murray.

title: Deutsche Bank Agrees to Pay €15 Million in Money-Laundering Probe
summary: Frankfurt prosecutors close investigation into two bank employees. Deutsche Bank AG said Friday it agreed to pay €15 million ($16.6 million) in penalties to end a probe into possible money-laundering and tax evasion involving German clients, closing an investigation that featured a high-profile raid of the bank's Frankfurt headquarters in November 2018.

title: Defense Chief: U.S. Not Considering Sending 14,000 Troops to Mideast
summary: Mark Esper statement follows Wall Street Journal report on possible future deployments to the region. WASHINGTON-Defense Secretary Mark Esper said in a statement Friday that he is "not considering sending 14,000 troops" to the Middle East.

title: Creators of 'My Favorite Murder' Podcast Land a Deal With Scripps
summary: Arrangement underscores the growing importance of podcasts in the media landscape. The creators of a popular true-crime podcast have signed a deal worth at least $10 million with E.W. Scripps Co. 's Stitcher podcasting unit, according to people familiar with the agreement, signaling the nascent medium's rapid growth.

title: 'Malarkey': From Old-Timey Baseball to Biden's Campaign Bus
summary: The names of some early Irish-American ballplayers somehow became a term for nonsense-and a favorite expression of the former vice president. This week, former Vice President Joe Biden has been barnstorming through Iowa for his presidential campaign on what he calls the "No Malarkey" tour. That phrase is even emblazoned on Mr. Biden's tour bus, in an echo of John McCain's "Straight Talk Express" from his 2000 and 2008 presidential races.

title: 'Hitler: A Global Biography' Review: His Enemy Across the Ocean
summary: The Nazi leader envied America's wealth and success. This obsession shaped his most terrifying acts.. On July 17, 1918, in the waning months of World War I, Pvt. Adolf Hitler of the 16th Bavarian Reserve Regiment escorted two American prisoners to brigade headquarters. The encounter with his prisoners changed Hitler's life, according to Brendan Simms in his fascinating "Hitler: A Global Biography." From that day on, the Austrian soldier-and, soon, the war veteran-turned-racist ideologue-convinced himself that the doughboys were in fact descendants of sturdy German emigrants to the New World whom the Fatherland had allowed to slip away. They had now, in Mr. Simms's words, "returned as avengers in the ranks of an unstoppable enemy." Stopping that unstoppable enemy, America, became Hitler's lifelong obsession-an obsession that, according to Mr. Simms, led to the creation of the Third Reich and eventually to Auschwitz and World War II.

title: Harvey Weinstein Has Repeatedly Violated His Bail Agreement, Prosecutors Say
summary: Prosecutors cite 56 violations on his monitoring device; his lawyers call them 'technical glitches'. New York prosecutors asked a judge Friday to increase Harvey Weinstein's bail, saying the Hollywood producer had violated his release conditions dozens of times before his coming sex-crimes trial.

title: A Couple Mysteries in Otherwise Pristine Jobs Report
summary: Investors are right to be pleased with November's strong jobs growth. But a couple details in the report may leave them scratching their heads.. There is plenty for investors to like about the November jobs report. There are also some things to puzzle over.

title: An Oenophile's Tour of Denver
summary: How's the wine at 5,000 feet? On a recent visit, our wine columnist found it thoughtfully chosen and poured, impressive in its variety and widely available-depending on the day of the week. Here's her list of top spots. THE MILE HIGH CITY is a beer and cocktail town-so I was told over and over again during a recent visit. According to the Denver wine merchants, wine bar owners, sommeliers and restaurateurs I polled, their city doesn't rank particularly high among great American wine cities. One wine bar owner even ranked it "around 20th." (Everyone I talked to ranked New York number one.) But after three days there, I'd rate Denver much higher. It may even be my new favorite wine town.

title: Margaret Thatcher's Battle Over Europe
summary: Debates about the U.K.'s role on the continent shaped-and helped to end-her tenure as prime minister.. The Conservatives led Britain into Europe. Now they are leading it out. Britain joined the future European Union-then the European Economic Community (EEC)-on January 1, 1973, under the Conservative government of Edward Heath. If the Conservative government of Boris Johnson wins the general election on December 12, Britain will leave the EU. The leading figure in this story is Margaret Thatcher.

title: Bank of Canada Governor Stephen Poloz to Step Down
summary: 'My time as governor has been the most fulfilling of my long career.'. OTTAWA-Bank of Canada Governor Stephen Poloz said Friday he will step down from his position when his term expires next June, after overseeing an economy sideswiped by a commodity-price downturn and weakened by trade uncertainty fueled by the Trump administration.

title: Singapore Hits the Brakes On Electric Scooters, But That Doesn't Stop Renegade Riders
summary: New law confines devices to designated bicycle routes and a few mixed-use paths; Fans are figuring out workarounds.. SINGAPORE-Sarah Alatas's morning commute used to be a breezy, 20-minute zip along tree-lined lanes on her Electrowolf Cyclone-a lightweight, foldable electric scooter that can whisk her across 50 miles of pavement on a single battery charge.

title: What Nervous Investors Are Buying to Feel Brave
summary: A buffered annuity protects against market declines. Until those declines get serious.. One of Wall Street's hottest investments lets you participate in most of the gains on stocks while sidestepping some of the losses.

title: A British Test for the Populist Revolution
summary: If Boris Johnson's pro-Brexit Tories capture a large portion of former Labour voters in next week's election, it will transform British politics and galvanize conservatives across the West. A country that likes to consider itself the most stable of democracies, a model of government typified by steady, pragmatic, get-things-done-with-no-drama progress, has descended in a few years into southern European-style political chaos.

title: How 'No Loan' College Works (It Doesn't Mean Free)
summary: Graduating without college debt is an attractive prospect. But students need to understand the basics of no-loan financial aid and how it might apply to them before making any decisions.. With all that has been written and said about the dangers of taking on too much debt to go to college, schools with no-loan financial-aid policies may sound like a dream.

title: Mysteries: To Nosh and Die in L.A.
summary: This delightful debut novel introduces Amos Parisman, a detective investigating the death of a controversial rabbi-and the subsequent murder of the rabbi's doctor.. Amos Parisman, the aging narrator of Andy Weinberger's delightful debut novel, "An Old Man's Game" (Prospect Park, 222 pages, $16), seems miscast as a Los Angeles private detective. A Vietnam vet still suffering flashbacks and slowed by a number of age-related ailments, Amos motors around town wearing a blue Dodgers baseball cap (to shield him from the sun, not out of loyalty) and bemoans the fact that L.A.'s rush hour lasts "from 6 a.m. to midnight."

title: 'The Depositions' Review: There Is a Balm in Milford
summary: Masterly essays on love and death from a funeral director in small-town America.. Thomas Lynch was 10 years old or so when he first saw a dead body. As he recalls in "The Depositions," his moving collection of previously published and new essays, the deceased was a tall, elderly man with generous earlobes, a pointy nose and thick glasses, although it was clear that the fellow wouldn't be needing the spectacles anymore.

title: Five Best: Sara Wheeler on Siberia
summary: From the author, most recently, of 'Mud and Stars: Travels in Russia With Pushkin, Tolstoy and Other Geniuses of the Golden Age.'. By Anton Chekhov (translated by Rosamund Bartlett, Anthony Phillips, Luba Terpak and Michael Terpak, 2007)

title: 'Big Sister, Little Sister, Red Sister' Review: Money, Power and China
summary: Ailing and her businessman husband grew extremely wealthy. Meiling married Nationalist Chiang Kai-shek. Qingling wed Sun Yat-sen but later backed Mao.. Once upon a time, a wealthy man lived in Shanghai with his devoutly Christian wife, with whom he had three sons and three daughters. The girls grew up to be educated, cultured and stylish, and their family's money and status attracted many aspiring suitors. In an era when China was experiencing significant political upheaval, each sister married an influential man and secured her position at the top of society. Their selection of husbands appeared to crystallize an essential aspect of each woman's character, as summed up by an oft-repeated saying: "One loved money, one loved power and one loved China."

title: 'Crystal Eastman' Review: The Vote Was Just the Beginning
summary: Tall, glamorous and brilliant, Crystal Eastman was the golden girl of American progressivism in the 1910s.. A century ago,Crystal Eastman was the golden girl of American progressivism. Tall, glamorous and brilliant, she held degrees from Vassar, Columbia and New York University School of Law. She was in the front rank of reformers working for women's rights, civil liberties, labor law, peace and the socialists' vision of a world government.

title: Fiction: The Flaming Sword of Justice and Irony
summary: The Catholic writer John L'Heureux, who left the priesthood at 36, depicted collisions of divine will and human nature.. 'The truth does not change according to our ability to stomach it emotionally," Flannery O'Connor wrote in a letter to a longtime correspondent. "A higher paradox confounds emotion as well as reason and there are long periods in the lives of all of us, and of the saints, when the truth as revealed by faith is hideous, emotionally disturbing, downright repulsive."

title: Children's Books: Hilarity for the Holidays
summary: Spending the season with Uri the Unwise, Fischel the Foolish, and Simon the Simple-minded.. What with Christmas trees and giant menorahs having popped up all over the place well before Thanksgiving, it may feel as though Hanukkah and the Yuletide celebrations are already upon us. Not so! We still have more than two weeks to prepare for the festivities, perhaps (ahem) with the help of some new children's books that draw on seasonal themes.

title: 'The Battle Between the Frogs and the Mice' Review: The Lighter Side of Homer
summary: An ancient parody of the 'Iliad' imagined a faceoff between armies of frogs and mice sporting cabbage-leaf shields and chickpea helmets.. 'Perhaps the best as well as oldest Burlesque in the World": So Samuel Wesley, in the dedication to his 1726 translation, assessed the "Batrachomyomachia," or "Battle of Frogs and Mice." By "burlesque" he meant not that the creatures took their clothes off (though the putting on of clothes, or rather armor, provides two of the highlights of the text) but that this was a mock-heroic spoof: in his words, "the Iliad in a nutshell." Its meter is Homer's dactylic hexameter, of which the best-known English example is Longfellow's "Evangeline": "This is the forest primeval. / The murmuring pines and the hemlocks . . ."

title: 'The Shadow of Vesuvius' Review: Two Lives Forever Entwined
summary: Pliny the Elder was endlessly inquisitive about the world. His nephew inclined toward self-scrutiny.. The century that began with the death of Augustus, in A.D. 14, was an eventful era for imperial Rome. Twelve caesars came and went, including three whose insane behavior prompted revolts or assassinations and three others who held power for only a few months. The boundaries of exploration expanded, leading to encounters with strange new phenomena across the known world. Near the midpoint of this time span, Mount Vesuvius erupted spectacularly and buried Pompeii and Herculaneum, killing thousands.

title: Today's Logistics Report: Electrified Supply Chains; Suing Online Commerce; Cybersecurity for Suppliers
summary: Today's Top Supply Chain and Logistics News from WSJ. Sign up: With one click, get this newsletter delivered to your inbox.

title: Canadian Economy Shed Jobs in November
summary: Decline marks sharp retrenchment for a jobs market that has largely been a bright spot for domestic economy. OTTAWA-The Canadian economy unexpectedly shed jobs in November and the unemployment rate rose to its highest level in more than a year, marking a sharp retrenchment for a jobs market that has largely been a bright spot in recent years.

title: Where Reddit's Co-Founder Finds His Own Community
summary: Alexis Ohanian turns to his wife Serena Williams and venture capital colleagues for inspiration, guidance and life lessons; 'There's an amazing amount of arrogance required as a business leader to think you don't need coaching.'. Alexis Ohanian helped build Reddit into a wildly popular news and discussion site online. He now wishes he had done it a little differently.

title: Supply Isn't the Problem With Organ Transplants
summary: There are plenty of donors to meet the need, but the system is so inefficient that available organs often don't reach desperate patients. One of the first things that transplant doctors learn is that there are not enough organs to go around. We repeat it to our patients and ourselves and, in a way, it helps us to temper our expectations of saving every patient on our waiting list. But there isn't really an organ shortage. We are just failing to make effective use of the organs that we could transplant.

title: Baseball Ownership: Keeping Up With the Ballmers
summary: With Steve Cohen's Mets purchase, there may finally be a really rich team owner. Even if the New York Mets stink it up again on the field next year, they may have a new swagger. So might the 29 other teams in Major League Baseball.

title: November Jobs Report Affirms Fed Officials' Make-No-Moves Stance
summary: The question now is how long to stay there. Federal Reserve officials will feel comfortable maintaining their wait-and-see posture on interest rates after Friday's report showing robust hiring in November.

title: Elizabeth Warren's Doctor Says She Is in Excellent Health
summary: Massachusetts senator is the first major presidential candidate to release results of a physical exam. WASHINGTON-Democratic presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren released results from her annual physical examination, making her the first of the top-tier 2020 candidates to continue a tradition of U.S. presidential contenders making their health details public.

title: Democrats Scrutinize Party's Diversity After Harris Exit
summary: Role of televised debates and a focus on picking a candidate seen as 'electable' are criticized. Sen. title: If Bitcoin Looks Like It Isn't Trading, It's Because It Isn't
summary: About 9.1 million bitcoins, representing about 51% of those outstanding, haven't changed hands in at least six months. On Dec. 17, 2017, bitcoin hit its highest level ever-$19,783. title: The Winner (or Loser) of the SEC Championship Could Be Utah
summary: Utes fans want to break into the College Football Playoff. But they might be stymied by the SEC-again.. SALT LAKE CITY-Everything was going right for Utah's football team. The Utes had just clinched their second consecutive Pac-12 championship appearance, and they were about to learn how much closer they were to the College Football Playoff when coach Kyle Whittingham gathered his players last Saturday. And then he mentioned another team.

title: Black Friday's Winners and Losers
summary: Shopping is shifting online, but not all retailers struggled to draw shoppers on Black Friday. Consumers continue to make more of their holiday purchases online, but new data indicate which retailers did a better job of attracting shoppers to their stores on Black Friday.

summary: Resume Subscription. Investors in dollar debt backed by one of China's largest cities may find themselves with a much shorter haircut before the winter holidays. One date to watch: Dec. 16.

title: U.S. GDP Doesn't Include Proceeds of Crime. Should It?
summary: Sales of illegal drugs would have added $111 billion to U.S. gross domestic product, according to estimate. When the U.S. calculates its gross domestic product, it only includes things that are legal. But if the wares of drug dealers, pimps, bookies and other black-market denizens were included, the GDP would expand by more than 1%, according to one estimate.

title: Big Tobacco Is a Long Way From Burning Out
summary: The threat of harsher regulations has hit cigarette stocks, but the industry may be more resilient than investors think. Cigarette stocks haven't been this beaten down since a spate of court cases led to multi-billion dollar settlements two decades ago. But the sector's current challenges will probably unfold more slowly than investors think.

title: States' Shift From Caucuses Is Challenge for Sanders, Warren
summary: Obama 2008 path to victory through caucuses is far less doable in 2020. Sen. Bernie Sanders built his strong 2016 campaign against Hillary Clinton with victories in a series in caucuses, the in-person gatherings that reward candidates who have organizing muscle and passionate followings.

title: New Senator's Cryptocurrency, NYSE Ties Make for Tricky Balancing Act
summary: Kelly Loeffler's appointment puts executive in position to oversee her former regulators; anti-Trump conservatives want some impeachment action. THE APPOINTMENT OF KELLY LOEFFLER as the next senator from Georgia puts a top financial executive in a position to oversee her former company's regulators. Loeffler spent more than a decade as a senior executive at Intercontinental Exchange Inc., or ICE, the parent company of the New York Stock Exchange and other market platforms. Last year, she became CEO of a digital-currencies trading and storage project that faced repeated delays in winning regulatory approval. Her husband, Jeffrey Sprecher, is the CEO of ICE. Sprecher owns a 1.12% stake in ICE, which is worth around $580 million based on the company's current market capitalization.

title: Michael Dell's Money Managers Change How His Wealth Is Invested

summary: Leaders promote training for jobs in an economy shifting toward services and domestic demand. XI'AN, China-A vast labor pool once powered China's economy. title: A World With a Billion Cameras Watching You Is Just Around the Corner
summary: Global numbers to grow almost 30% as higher image quality allows better facial recognition. As governments and companies invest more in security networks, hundreds of millions more surveillance cameras will be watching the world in 2021, mostly in China, according to a new report.

summary: Bounce in employment is expected to reflect GM workers returning from a strike, while the jobless rate remains stable around historically low levels. Uber Technologies Inc. said it received 5,981 reports of sexual assault involving U.S. passengers or drivers during 2017 and 2018, underscoring the risk that has been a chief criticism of ride-hailing companies around the world.

title: California Bans Insurers From Dropping Homes in Wildfire Areas
summary: One-year moratorium applies to 800,000 homes in risky locales, with more likely to be added. California regulators temporarily banned insurers from refusing to renew home-insurance policies in certain wildfire-prone parts of the state in an effort to halt an insurance-availability crisis.

title: Pelosi Says Democrats Will Draw Up Articles of Impeachment
summary: The president 'abused his power for his own personal political benefit,' House speaker says. summary: Demand for firearms has improved even as some retailers restrict sales of guns, ammo. American Outdoor Brands Inc. provided more evidence that demand for guns was stabilizing, with full-year sales and profit guidance that topped analysts' expectations.

title: Adam Schiff Is Watching
summary: Obtaining phone logs of political rivals is a stunning abuse of congressional power.. Fanatics can justify any action, and House Intelligence Chairman Adam Schiff this week demonstrated where that mindset leads. In his rush to paint Donald Trump as a lawbreaker, Mr. Schiff has himself trampled law and responsibility.

title: Republicans Suppress Their Own Voters
summary: Eight state parties have canceled 2020 contests or limited them to Trump.. The Georgia and North Carolina Republican parties decided this week that Donald Trump will be the only name on their 2020 presidential primary ballots, and they aren't alone. The Minnesota Republican Party pulled the same move a few weeks ago, and earlier the parties in South Carolina, Arizona, Kansas, Nevada and Alaska canceled their nominating contests outright. The party is disenfranchising GOP voters in eight states-so far.

title: Don't Believe in God? Lie to Your Children
summary: The alternative is to tell them they're simply going to die and turn to dust.. As a therapist, I'm often asked to explain why depression and anxiety are so common among children and adolescents. One of the most important explanations-and perhaps the most neglected-is declining interest in religion. This cultural shift already has proved disastrous for millions of vulnerable young people.

title: 'Wildhood' Review: When Creatures Come of Age
summary: Contemplating how we are like-and unlike-our friends in the animal kingdom, using the phenomenon of adolescence as an anchor.. Despite the word "adolescence" in the subtitle, "Wildhood: The Epic Journey From Adolescence to Adulthood in Humans and Other Animals" is not a parenting book. It is not a book about how modern life has ruined childhood or severed our connection to nature. And it certainly doesn't suggest that we take lessons on raising teenagers from hyenas, though that might not be such a bad idea.

title: Iran-Contra Was a Better Class of Scandal
summary: It arose out of serious aims, not tawdry ones, and it holds lessons in resilience and perseverance.. During presidential scandals, members of the media often speak of the Iran-Contra affair. I'm not sure they really understand it.

title: Overtime, Gen Z Sports Oasis, Looks to Raise $40 Million
summary: The three-year old startup started as a distributor for high school basketball highlights. Overtime Sports Inc. is raising an additional $40 million to fund the startup's quest to attract Generation Z consumers, the next big focus for marketers that cater to young people.

title: Wealth Tax Is a Decent Idea, Though Probably Unconstitutional
summary: Most economic objections apply to the income tax as well. But 16th Amendment permits the latter.. The idea of a wealth tax has been in the news of late, mainly because of campaign proposals from Sens. Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren. Commentators mostly paint the issue in stark black or white: A tax on wealth is either a marvelous idea, essential to reducing inequality in America, or a horrible idea destined to fail. A more accurate portrayal would concentrate on shades of gray.

title: Britain's Anything-and-Everything Brexit Election
summary: Voters figure out they need to pick a new path for the country before they leave the European Union.. Of course the U.K.'s impending "Brexit election" looks like it's about anything and everything except Brexit.

title: Democrats Want to Invade Mexico
summary: They're demanding a U.S. right to enforce another country's labor laws in the trade deal.. House Democrat Richard Neal declared the other day that "we are on the 2 1/2-yard line" of a revised trade deal with Mexico and Canada. The trouble is that Democrats keep pulling the football away from U.S. Trade Rep Robert Lighthizer. Now they're essentially demanding that U.S. unions be allowed to enforce labor laws in Mexico.

title: Bloomberg's Education Opening
summary: Charter schools would help him break from the Democratic pack.. Michael Bloomberg had some good news this week when both the Morning Consult and Hill-HarrisX polls showed support doubling for his presidential run. Though he's still in single digits- Hill-HarrisX puts him at 6%-there's room to move up if he can distinguish himself from other Democrats.

title: Want to Date a Colleague? Think Carefully
summary: Company policies about office relationships vary, but for senior leaders, message increasingly is 'just say no'. Companies have increased scrutiny of consensual relationships among colleagues in the wake of the #MeToo movement. Whatever the corporate dating policy is, the underlying message to senior executives is: Just don't do it.
